The user drags a rectangle loosely around an object. The object is then extracted automatically.AbstractThe problem of efficient, interactive foreground/background seg- mentation in still images is of great practical importance in im- age editing. Classical image segmentation tools use either texture (colour) information, e.g. Magic Wand, or edge (contrast) infor- mation, e.g. Intelligent Scissors. Recently, an approach based on optimization by graph-cut has been developed which successfully combines both types of information. In this paper we extend the graph-cut approach in three respects. First, we have developed a more powerful, iterative version of the optimisation. Secondly, the power of the iterative algorithm is used to simplify substantially the user interaction needed for a given quality of result. Thirdly, a ro- bust algorithm for ‚Äúborder matting‚Äù has been developed to estimate simultaneously the alpha-matte around an object boundary and the colours of foreground pixels. We show|there is no flow from the source to the sink (f = 0) and edge capacities in the residual graph G0 are equal to the original capacities in G. At each new iteration, the algorithm finds the shortest s ! t path along nonsaturated edges of the residual graph. If a path is found, then the algorithm augments it by pushing the maximum possible flow df that saturates at least one of the edges in the path. The residual capacities of edges in the path are reduced by df while the residual capacities of the reverse edges are increased by df. Each augmentation increases the total flow from the source to the sink f ¬º f √æ df. The maximum flow is reached when any s ! t path crosses at least one saturated edge in the residual graph Gf.The Dinic algorithm uses breadth-first search to find the shortest paths from s to t on the residual graph Gf. After all shortest paths of a fixed length k are saturated, algorithm starts the breadth-first search for s ! t paths of length k √æ 1 from scratch. Note that the use of shortest paths is an important factor that improves theoretical running time complexities for algorithms based on augmenting paths. The worst-case running time complexity for the Dinic|as the mask parameter of grabCut when conducting further interactions.Now let‚Äôs try this method. When the algorith successfully finds the|¬Æ ‚Äî\GrabCut" | Interactive Foreground Extraction using Iterated Graph CutsCarsten Rother*Vladimir Kolmogorov* Microsoft Research Cambridge, UKAndrew Blake*Figure 1: Three examples of GrabCut. The user drags a rectangle loosely around an object. The object is then extracted automatically.AbstractThe problem of efficient, interactive foreground/background seg- mentation in still images is of great practical importance in im- age editing. Classical image segmentation tools use either texture (colour) information, e.g. Magic Wand, or edge (contrast) infor- mation, e.g. Intelligent Scissors. Recently, an approach based on optimization by graph-cut has been developed which successfully combines both types of information. In this paper we extend the graph-cut approach in three respects. First, we have developed a more powerful, iterative version of the optimisation. Secondly, the power of the iterative algorithm is used to simplify substantially the user interaction needed for a given quality of result. Thirdly, a ro- bust algorithm for ‚Äúborder matting‚Äù has been developed to estimate simultaneously the alpha-matte around an object boundary and the colours of foreground pixels. We show|there is no flow from the source to the sink (f = 0) and edge capacities in the residual graph G0 are equal to the original capacities in G. At each new iteration, the algorithm finds the shortest s ! t path along nonsaturated edges of the residual graph. If a path is found, then the algorithm augments it by pushing the maximum possible flow df that saturates at least one of the edges in the path. The residual capacities of edges in the path are reduced by df while the residual capacities of the reverse edges are increased by df. Each augmentation increases the total flow from the source to the sink f ¬º f √æ df. The maximum flow is reached when any s ! t path crosses at least one saturated edge in the residual graph Gf.The Dinic algorithm uses breadth-first search to find the shortest paths from s to t on the residual graph Gf. After all shortest paths of a fixed length k are saturated, algorithm starts the breadth-first search for s ! t paths of length k √æ 1 from scratch. Note that the use of shortest paths is an important factor that improves theoretical running time complexities for algorithms based on augmenting paths. The worst-case running time complexity for the Dinic|as the mask parameter of grabCut when conducting further interactions.Now let‚Äôs try this method. input: What is the purpose of the Transformer in the Vision Transformer (ViT) model?
actual_output: Based on the provided context, the purpose of the Transformer in the Vision Transformer (ViT) model is to process sequences of image patches for image recognition tasks. Specifically: 1. The image is divided into fixed-size patches (e.g., 16x16 pixels), which are linearly projected into embeddings. 2. These patch embeddings, along with positional encodings and an extra learnable [class] embedding, are fed into a standard Transformer encoder architecture. 3. The Transformer encoder uses self-attention mechanisms to model relationships between all patches, allowing it to capture global context and dependencies across the entire image, unlike Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) which primarily focus on local features through convolutional filters. This approach enables ViT to achieve state-of-the-art performance in image recognition, especially when pre-trained on large-scale datasets, as referenced in the arXiv preprint (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020)[citation:./documents/Swain1.pdf]. If you'd like more details on how ViT compares to CNNs or its components, feel free to ask! **Cited Materials:** Lec 9 CNN
expected_output: The Transformer in a Vision Transformer (ViT) model is used to capture both local and global relationships within an image by treating the image as a sequence of patches.

The asymptotic complexity of Incremental In- tersection is O(n log n + cm), where c is the number of image bins used for indexing into the database. The complexity of Incremental Intersection is also linear in the size of the database.

input: What is the main difference between CNNs and ViTs?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context from the course materials, I can explain the main differences between Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Vision Transformers (ViTs). **Main Differences Between CNNs and ViTs:** 1. **Architectural Approach:** - CNNs use convolutional layers that apply filters to local regions of an image, capturing spatial hierarchies and local features through weight sharing and pooling. - ViTs, as shown in the context, use a Transformer Encoder architecture. They split the image into fixed-size patches, linearly project them into embeddings (with added positional information), and process them using self-attention mechanisms to capture global context. 2. **Inductive Biases:** - CNNs have built-in inductive biases for images, such as translation invariance and locality, making them data-efficient for vision tasks. - ViTs have fewer built-in inductive biases for images; they rely on self-attention to learn spatial relationships from data, which often requires large-scale training. 3. **Handling of Image Data:** - CNNs process images in their raw spatial form through convolutional operations. - ViTs treat image patches as sequences (similar to words in NLP), enabling them to model long-range dependencies effectively. **Is CNN better than ViT?** According to the retrieved context (from Dosovitskiy et al., 2020), the answer is **False** (B: False). This suggests that ViTs can outperform CNNs in certain scenarios, especially when trained on large datasets, though the performance depends on the specific task and data size. For more details, you might refer to the lecture materials or contact Dr. Tissa Chandesa (Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my) or the teaching assistant Mr. Irfan Yaqub (hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my) during office hours. **Cited Materials:** Practicals CNN Practicals with Solutions CNN
expected_output: CNNs use convolutional layers to extract features from an image, which are inherently local operations. ViTs, on the other hand, divide the image into patches and use a Transformer architecture to learn relationships between these patches, allowing them to capture more global context.

input: What is the purpose of zero-padding in convolutional layers?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context from the lecture materials, the purpose of zero-padding in convolutional layers is **to add zeros to every side of the input boundaries**. This ensures that the filters fit the input image properly during convolution operations. More specifically, zero-padding helps in: - Preserving the spatial dimensions of the input (preventing the output feature map from shrinking too quickly) - Allowing the filter to properly cover the edges and corners of the input image - Maintaining structural information at the borders This technique is a key hyperparameter in convolutional layers, alongside the number of filters and stride, to control the size and shape of the output feature maps. **Source:** Lecture notes (Lec-9-CNN.pdf) ‚Äì "Zero-padding adds zeroes to every side of the input boundaries ‚Äì ensures filters fit the input image." **Cited Materials:** Lec 9 CNN
expected_output: Zero-padding is the process of adding zeros around the border of an input image before applying a convolutional filter. This is done to control the spatial size of the output feature map and to ensure that the filter can be applied to pixels at the edge of the image.

input: What is stride in a convolutional layer?
actual_output: Of course! Let's break down what "stride" means in a convolutional layer. In simple terms, **stride** is the number of pixels the filtering window (or kernel) moves across the input image after each convolution operation. Here's a more detailed explanation: * When a filter (e.g., a 3x3 kernel) performs a convolution, it starts at the top-left corner of the image. * After calculating the dot product for that position, it needs to move to the next location. * The **stride** defines the size of this step or "jump." The most common stride values are: * **Stride = 1**: The filter moves one pixel at a time. This results in a large, detailed output feature map that is only slightly smaller than the input. * **Stride = 2**: The filter moves two pixels at a time. This downsamples the output, making the feature map smaller and reducing its dimensionality. **Why is stride important?** * **Larger Strides (e.g., 2)**: Reduce the spatial size of the output feature maps, which decreases the computational load and the number of parameters in subsequent layers. It also helps to provide a form of translation invariance. * **Smaller Strides (e.g., 1)**: Preserve more spatial information, leading to more detailed feature maps but requiring more computation. This definition is supported by the retrieved context from the lecture materials, which states: > "Stride - # of pixels the filtering window moves after each operation" (Source: `./documents/Lec-9-CNN.pdf`) I hope this clarifies the concept! Let me know if you have any other questions. **Cited Materials:** Lec 9 CNN
expected_output:
Stride is the number of pixels by which the filter moves across the image at each step. A stride of 1 means the filter moves one pixel at a time, while a stride of 2 means it moves two pixels at a time, resulting in a smaller output feature map.

input: What are the deliverables for the coursework?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context from the assessment sheet, the deliverables for the COMP 2032 Introduction to Image Processing coursework are as follows: **Per group submission (groups of 4 students):** 1. **Python codes** - These should be submitted as `.py` files, contained within a ZIP folder. 2. **A 6-page conference paper** - This should be a maximum of 2000 words and submitted in PDF format. Please note that submitting additional pages beyond the 6-page limit will result in a mark deduction. This coursework is worth **50%** of your overall module grade. For the most detailed and official information, please always refer to the latest version of the **Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf** on Moodle or contact the module convenor, Dr. Tissa Chandesa (Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my), if you have any specific questions. **Source:** `./documents/Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf` **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025
expected_output: The coursework requires a group submission of Python code files (as a ZIP folder), a 6-page conference paper (2000 words max, PDF format), and result images (as a ZIP folder). There is also an individual submission of a peer assessment form.

input: What is the topic of the coursework?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context, the coursework for the Introduction to Image Processing module (COMP2032) is assessed by a 100% coursework component. The topic involves: * **Programming:** Writing a Python application. * **A 2000-word conference paper:** This paper should include a literature review, an explanation of your work, and an evaluation of your results. This information is sourced from the lecture slides: `./documents/Lec-1A-Introduction.pdf`. For the most specific and detailed guidelines on the coursework, including the exact problem statement and submission deadlines, you should consult the official assignment brief on Moodle or contact the module convenor, **Dr. Tissa Chandesa** (Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my). **Cited Materials:** Lec 1A Introduction

input: What are the main parts of the coursework?
actual_output: Based on the provided context, the main parts of the COMP2032 coursework are as follows: 1. **A Programming Component**: You are required to develop a Python application. 2. **A 2000-word Conference Paper**: This is a written report in a specific format (a 6-page max PDF) that should include a literature review, an explanation of your work, and an evaluation of your results. 3. **An In-Lab Test**: This is a component you must complete, answering all questions. The context suggests this may be done individually. 4. **Peer Assessment**: Each group member must individually submit a peer assessment form. Failure to do so will result in a 10% penalty on the overall group mark. 5. **Result Images**: You must submit a ZIP folder containing the output images from your work. This is a **group assessment**, though the in-lab test and peer assessment are individual components. For the most precise and official instructions, please always refer to the latest version of the **"Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf"** provided on Moodle[^citation3]. [^citation3]: Information sourced from: ./documents/Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025
expected_output: The coursework has two main parts: a SEGMENTATION PART where you design and implement an image processing pipeline to segment flowers from images in Dataset 1, and a SEMANTIC PART where you classify the entire flower dataset (Dataset 2) using a provided Transformer-based model.

input: What are the requirements for the output images in the segmentation part?
actual_output: Based on the provided context, the requirements for the output images in the segmentation part are as follows: 1. **File Format**: Output images must be saved as `.jpg` or `.png` files. 2. **Image Size & Resolution**: Output images should ideally be **256√ó256 pixels**. If your segmentation output is a different size, it will be automatically resized, which may cause distortions. 3. **Content**: The output image must have a **black background with only the segmented flower** visible. 4. **Folder Structure**: - Output images should be saved in an output folder, categorized into three sub-folders: `easy`, `medium`, and `hard`. - Each output image should have the same name as the corresponding input image. 5. **Automatic Processing**: Your solution should operate on all provided images without user intervention, using one parameter set for all. These requirements ensure that your segmentation results can be properly evaluated using metrics like **Cosine Similarity** and **Accuracy**, as outlined in the guidelines. If you need further clarification, feel free to ask! **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025
expected_output: The output images must have a black background with only the segmented flower. They should be saved as .jpg files in an "output" folder, categorized into sub-folders named "easy," "medium," and "hard," corresponding to the input images.

input: What evaluation metrics should be used for the segmentation part?
actual_output: Based on the provided lecture materials, the segmentation evaluation model uses two specific metrics to assess your segmentation results: 1. **Cosine Similarity**: This metric measures the high-level similarity between your segmented images and the provided ground truth masks. It produces a score ranging from 0 to 1, where a higher score indicates better performance. 2. **Accuracy**: This metric measures pixel-wise accuracy between your segmented masks and the ground truth, evaluating how many pixels are correctly classified. These metrics are designed to evaluate segmentation quality from both a structural (cosine similarity) and a detailed pixel-level (accuracy) perspective. For your coursework submission, ensure your segmented images and ground truth masks meet the format requirements (.jpg or .png) and are properly organized in the specified folder structure as outlined in the guidelines. *Source: Guidelines for Using the Segmentation Evaluation Model* **Cited Materials:** Guidelines for Using the Segmentation Evaluation Model
expected_output: The evaluation of the segmentation pipeline can be both qualitative and quantitative. The coursework suggests using mean IoU (Intersection over Union) as a metric.

input: What is the purpose of Dataset 1?
actual_output: I'm sorry, but I don't have enough context to answer your question about the purpose of "Dataset 1." The retrieved materials provided don't contain specific information about different datasets or their purposes. For clarification on the specific datasets used in your image processing module, I recommend: 1. **Contacting the module convenor:** Dr. Tissa Chandesa (Email: Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my) 2. **Speaking with the teaching assistant:** Mr. Irfan Yaqub (Email: hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my) 3. **Reviewing your course materials** or checking the official module documentation for details about specific datasets They will be able to provide you with accurate information about Dataset 1 and its purpose in your image processing coursework. You can contact the module convenor directly for clarification on Dataset 1: Email Dr. Chandesa
expected_output: Dataset 1 contains images of three species of flowers, categorized into "easy," "medium," and "hard" sub-folders, along with their corresponding ground truths. This dataset is to be used for developing and evaluating the image processing pipeline for the segmentation part of the coursework.

input: What is the purpose of Dataset 2?
actual_output: Based on the provided context from the Assessment Sheet, **Dataset 2** is used for the **semantic segmentation part** of the coursework. Specifically, the context states: > "Dataset 2: This consists of 847 images with its corresponding ground truths. You are to use this dataset when fulfilling the semantic part (detailed below)." Source: `./documents/Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf` **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025

input: What are the requirements for the conference paper?
actual_output: Based on the provided context from the assessment sheet, the requirements for the conference paper are as follows: 1. **Format:** It must be a 6-page conference paper, submitted in PDF format. Please note that there is a strict page limit; any additional pages will result in a penalty of **5% deducted from the entire group's mark for every extra page**. 2. **Content:** When writing your paper, you must address these points: * Detail the chosen image processing method(s) and specific technique(s) you employed. * Explain why you chose those specific techniques and methods. You may include pseudocode for them if applicable. * Present the results obtained from your practical implementation. * Critically evaluate your method(s) based on those results, discussing their strengths and weaknesses. This evaluation must make explicit reference to features in your results and use the **relevant metric for segmentation** to support your arguments. * Critically evaluate your classification results, highlighting the strengths and weaknesses of your entire processing pipeline by performing a **pixel-wise classification**. You must use the **cosine similarity and accuracy metrics** generated from your semantic part to support your arguments. 3. **Template:** You must use the provided template document (`COMP2032-CW-GroupXXX.docx`). You are to replace the "XXX" in the filename with your three-digit group number (e.g., Group 13 would use `COMP2032-CW-Group013.docx`). **It is very important that you do not change the formatting and headers** of this template, as marks will be deducted for incorrect formatting. Text colored in red and blue in the template is placeholder text that you must replace with your own content. This information is sourced from the **Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf**. For any further clarification on these requirements, your primary contact is the module convenor, **Dr. Tissa Chandesa** (Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my). You can also consult the teaching assistant, **Mr. Irfan Yaqub** (hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my). **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025
expected_output: The conference paper should be a maximum of 6 pages (2000 words), detailing the chosen methods, justifying their selection, presenting the results, and critically evaluating the implemented pipeline and classification results. It must be submitted in PDF format using the provided template.

input: Are we allowed to modify the provided Transformer and Model_input Python files?
actual_output: Based on the provided context, I don't have specific information about whether you're allowed to modify the Transformer and Model_input Python files for your image processing module. The context mentions that in certain data loading implementations (like the MNIST dataset class), you're expected to maintain specific method names (`__init__`, `__getitem__`, `__len__`) but doesn't provide guidelines about modifying other files like Transformer or Model_input. For clarification on whether you can modify these specific files, I recommend: 1. **Contacting Dr. Tissa Chandesa** (Module Convenor) - Email: Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my - Office: Room BB71 Block B, Malaysia Campus 2. **Contacting the Teaching Assistant** - Mr Irfan Yaqub: hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my 3. **Checking your assignment instructions or module guidelines** for any specific rules about code modification 4. **Attending office hours** if available to get direct clarification It's always best to confirm with your instructors before modifying provided code files, as assignment requirements can vary significantly. *You can use the following button to email Dr. Chandesa for clarification:* Email Dr. Chandesa

input: What is the peer assessment form for?
actual_output: Based on the provided context, the peer assessment form is for you to evaluate your group members' contributions to the coursework project. According to the assessment sheet, each student must submit this form individually. The purpose is to provide a fair assessment of individual effort within the group work. **Failure to submit the peer assessment will result in a penalty of 10% of your overall group mark.** You can find and submit the form by clicking on the ‚ÄúPeer Assessment‚Äù link on your Moodle page for the COMP2032 module. For any specific questions about how to complete the form or what criteria it assesses, it is best to contact the module's teaching assistant, Mr. Irfan Yaqub, via email at `hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my`. **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025
expected_output: Each group member must individually submit a peer assessment form. Failure to do so will result in a 10% penalty on the overall group mark.

input: What are the assessment criteria for the coursework?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context from the assessment sheet, here are the coursework criteria for COMP2032: **Assessment Breakdown (100% Coursework):** This assessment consists of two main components: 1. **Group Project: Programming + 2000-word conference paper (50%)** * Development of a Python application. * A written report comprising a literature review, an explanation of your methodology, and an evaluation of your results. 2. **In-Lab Test (Individual) (50%)** * This test will focus on the theories covered in the lectures and practical exercises. * **Date, Time & Venue:** 29 April 2025 | 2:30pm till 3:30pm | TCR 1 * You must answer ALL questions. **Justification and Discussion (from the conference paper criteria):** The context also provides more detailed criteria that are likely part of the evaluation for the conference paper portion of the group project. These include: * **Justification of chosen algorithms** based on a performed literature review: **15%** * **Critical analysis and discussion of your findings:** **25%** * **Discussion of the strengths and weaknesses** of your proposed pipeline (based on your findings), prior to concluding on the classification result: **30%** **Very Important Note:** The context also contains a critical warning regarding the programming component: **"[unable to run codes will result in 0% being awarded]"** This means that if the Python application you submit does not run, it will result in a score of 0% for that entire component of the coursework. For the most precise and official breakdown, you should always refer to the official **Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf** document provided on Moodle. If you have any specific questions about the expectations for the literature review or the application, your first point of contact should be: **Dr. Tissa Chandesa** (Module Convenor) * **Email:** Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my **Source:** `./documents/Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf` **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025
expected_output: The Python code is worth 30%, and the conference paper is worth 70%. The paper is broken down into justification of algorithms (15%), critical analysis of findings (25%), and discussion of strengths and weaknesses (30%).

input: What is the format for the in-lab test?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context from the assessment documentation, the in-lab test for COMP2032 is described as follows: **Format:** * It is a **group** assessment. * Students are required to **answer ALL questions**. The provided context does not specify further details such as the test's duration, question types (e.g., practical coding, theory), or specific topics covered. For the most accurate and complete information regarding the test's structure, I recommend you: 1. Check the full assessment brief on Moodle. 2. Contact the module convenor, **Dr. Tissa Chandesa** (Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my), for clarification. He will be able to provide you with the definitive format and any other specifics you need to prepare. **Cited Materials:** Lec 1A Introduction
expected_output: The in-lab test is an individual assessment worth 50% of the final grade. It focuses on theories covered in the lectures and practical exercises.

The asymptotic complexity of Incremental In- tersection is O(n log n + cm), where c is the number of image bins used for indexing into the database. input: What is the meaning of life?
actual_output:
That's a profound philosophical question that has been contemplated for centuries! However, I'm here specifically to assist with topics related to the **Introduction to Image Processing** module.

If you have any questions about image processing concepts, techniques, algorithms, or assignments for this course, I'd be happy to help. For broader philosophical inquiries, you might want to consult resources or experts in philosophy or related fields.

Feel free to ask me anything about histogram operations, segmentation methods, min-cut/max-flow algorithms, or other image processing topics!
expected_output: I'm sorry, I can only answer questions related to image processing.

In fact, it can be shown that the fundamental modes of oscillation of this spring mass system are exactly the generalized eigenvectors of (6).Assuming the solution takes the form of x(t) = vpcos(wet + 0), the steady state solutions of this spring-mass system satisfy:Kv, = w{Mv,, (21)analogous to (6) for normalized cut.Each solution pair (w;, v,) of (21) describes a fundamental mode of the spring-mass system. The eigenvectors v; give the steady state displacement of the oscillation in each mode and the eigenvalues uz give the energy required to sustain each mode of oscillation. input: Can you tell me a joke?
actual_output:
I'm here to help with questions related to your Introduction to Image Processing module! Unfortunately, I can't tell jokes as that falls outside the scope of image processing topics.

input: What are the best programming languages to learn in 2025?
actual_output: I'm here to help with questions specifically about the **Introduction to Image Processing** module (COMP 2032), such as concepts, practicals, or coursework-related topics. Your question about the best programming languages to learn in 2025 is outside the scope of this module. For general programming language advice, I recommend consulting resources from computer science departments or career guidance services. If you have questions about image processing, like using Python for practical work (as mentioned in the coursework for this module), feel free to ask! **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025

input: Can you help me with my math homework?
actual_output:
I'm here to assist with topics related to the **Introduction to Image Processing** module, but I'm afraid I can't help with general math homework questions that fall outside this scope. If your question involves mathematical concepts directly applicable to image processing‚Äîsuch as segmentation algorithms, matrix operations for image transformations, or metrics like mean Intersection over Union (mIoU)‚Äîplease feel free to ask!

If you're working on an image processing assignment and need help with the math involved (e.g., understanding graph cuts, normalization in segmentation, or evaluating results), just provide more details, and I‚Äôll do my best to assist.

For other math-related inquiries, I recommend reaching out to your math tutor or lecturer, or using dedicated academic support services at your university. Let me know how I can help with image processing!
expected_output:
I'm sorry, I can only answer questions related to image processing.

Based on the provided context, the module convenor for COMP2032 (Introduction to Image Processing) is **Dr. Tissa Chandesa**.

His contact details are:

You can also contact the teaching assistant, Mr. Irfan Yaqub, at hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my if you have questions about the module.

input: How do I submit my coursework?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context, here's how to submit your coursework for the Introduction to Image Processing (COMP2032) module: **Group Submission (to be submitted once per group):** 1. **Python codes**: Submit your .py files as a ZIP folder. 2. **Conference paper**: A 6-page PDF document (max 2000 words). Use the provided template `COMP2032-CW-GroupXXX.docx` (replace XXX with your 3-digit group number). Do not change the formatting style. Additional pages beyond 6 will result in a 5% deduction per extra page for the entire group. 3. **Result Images**: Submit as a ZIP folder with specific folder names: "Output" and "Image Processing Pipeline". **Individual Submission:** 4. **Peer Assessment Form**: Each group member must submit this separately via the "Peer Assessment" link on Moodle. Failure to submit will result in a 10% penalty on your overall group mark. **Submission Deadline:** Friday, 25 April 2025, by 11:59 PM. Late submissions are penalized at 5 marks (5% of total) per working day late. **Feedback:** Marks and individual feedback will be returned via Moodle during the week of 2 June 2025. If you have further questions about submission logistics, please contact the module convenor, Dr. Tissa Chandesa (Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my), or the teaching assistant, Mr. Irfan Yaqub (hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my). **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025
expected_output: You submit your coursework through the Moodle assignment page.

input: What is the assessment criteria for the coursework?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context, the assessment criteria for the COMP2032 coursework (which is worth 50% of the overall module grade) is broken down as follows for the **Group Submission (Programming and Conference Paper)**: * **Justification of chosen algorithms based on performed literature review:** 15% * **Critical analysis and discussion of your findings:** 25% * **Discussion of the strengths and weaknesses of your proposed pipeline (based on your findings), prior to concluding on the classification result:** 30% * **(Implied from context) Functioning Python code / application:** The document states that being "unable to run codes will result in 0% being awarded," indicating that a significant portion of the remaining 30% is allocated to a working software solution. The deliverables for this group coursework are: 1. Python code files (submitted as a .ZIP folder). 2. A 6-page conference paper (2000 words maximum, in PDF format). Submitting additional pages will result in a mark deduction. **Important Note on the In-Lab Test:** The overall module assessment is 100% coursework, split into two parts: 1. **Group Programming and Conference Paper:** 50% (detailed above). 2. **Individual In-Lab Test:** 50%. This test will focus on theories covered in the lectures and practical exercises. It is scheduled for **29 April 2025, from 2:30pm to 3:30pm**. **Source:** The assessment breakdown and details are taken from the module's official assessment sheet and supporting documents (`Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025.pdf`). For the most precise and detailed marking scheme for the code itself, it is highly recommended to consult the official rubric provided by the module convenor, Dr. Tissa Chandesa (Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my), or the teaching assistant, Mr. Irfan Yaqub (hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my). They can provide the specific criteria used to evaluate the functionality and quality of the Python application. **Cited Materials:** Assessment Sheet COMP2032 Coursework 2025
expected_output:
The assessment criteria is as follows:
+Python code(s): 30% [unable to run codes will result in 0% being awarded]
+Conference Paper:
‚àí Justification of chosen algorithms based on performed literature review: 15%
‚àí Critical analysis and discussion of your findings: 25%
‚àí Discussion of the strengths and weaknesses of your proposed pipeline (based on your findings), prior to concluding on the classification result: 30%.
+In-Lab Test Individual (50%) - Focuses on theories covered in the lectures and practical exercises

input: Can I get an extension for the coursework?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context, I can see that the coursework submission deadline for Introduction to Image Processing (COMP 2032) is **Friday, 25 April 2025, by 11:59pm**. However, the provided context does not include any information about extension policies or procedures. This is a matter that falls outside the scope of image processing topics and is related to administrative and assessment rules. For questions about extensions, you should directly contact the module convenor: **Dr. Tissa Chandesa** Email: Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my Office: Room BB71 Block B, Malaysia Campus He will be able to provide you with the official university policy on extensions and guide you through the process if applicable. It's best to reach out to him as soon as possible with your request. *You can use the following button to contact Dr. Chandesa directly about your extension request:* Email Dr. Chandesa
expected_output: I‚Äôm not able to help you with an extension. You should contact the module convenor (Dr. Tissa Chandesa) and request a coursework extension, providing a reason for it.

For each pixel:If its neighbours are all unlabelled, give it a new label-If it has neighbours with a single label, it gets that labelIf it has neighbours with two or more labels, it is a watershed (W)-5  A  A  W C C  4  A  A  W W W  3  A  A  W B B  2  AA  W W B  1  AA  A W B 543216University of Nottingham UK | CHINA. | MALAYSIAThat‚Äôs ALL folks!Now, you know the answers!|Given a pair of histgrams, J and M, each containing n bins, the intersection of the histo- grams is defined to ben >) min (, Mj). j=lThe result of the intersection of a model histogram with an image histogram is the number of pixels from the model that have corresponding pixels of the same col- or in the image. To obtain a fractional match value between 0 and 1 the intersection is normalized by the numbcr of pixels in the model histogram. The match value is thenHG, M) = Lj-1 min, M;)The normalized histogram intersection match value is not reduced by distracting pixels in the background. This is the desired behavior since complete segmenta- tion of the object from the background cannot be guar- anteed. Segmentation is still a topic of active reserach, but the indications from the large amount of research done in the past are that complete, efficient, and reliable semgnetation cannot be done prior to recognition. The histogram intersection match value is only increased by a pixel in the background if ‚Äò‚Äî the pixel has the same color as one of the colors in the model, and‚Äî the number of pixels of that color in the object is less than the number of pixels of that color in the|by key.In the on-line phase:1. Sort the image histogram bins by size.2. For the B largest image bins, starting with the largest, match the image bin to all the model bins with the same index whose key is larger. If previously un- matched model bins are matched, match them to all larger image bins.100 99 Average Match 98-4 Percentile 97 96 + T 7 a -0 Tmage Histogram Bins MatchedFig. 15. Effectiveness of Incremental Intersection as function of the number of image histogram bins matched. For comparison, the average match percentile for Histogram Intersection is 99.86.The efficiency of Histogram Intersection and Incre- mental Intersection is compared in table 6. A complex- ity analysis shows that the time for Histogram Intersec- tion depends linearly on the product of the size of the histogram and the size of the database, ie., the algorithm is O(am), where nis the total number of bins in the histogram and m is the number of models in the database. The asymptotic complexity of Incremental In- tersection is O(n log n + cm), where c is the number of image bins used for indexing into the database. The complexity of Incremental Intersection is also linear in the size of the database.

input: What programming language is used in this module?
actual_output: Based on the provided context from the lab sheets, this module uses **Python** as the programming language for image processing tasks. Specifically, the OpenCV and Matplotlib libraries are utilized for image operations and data visualization, respectively. If you have any more questions about Python, OpenCV, or image processing concepts, I'm happy to help! **Cited Materials:** Lab 1A Lab 2
expected_output: This module provides practical experience of image processing using Python.
retrieval_context: import. The specified functions are imported, and the module does not need to be referenced.‚óè Using from‚Ä¶ import *. The entire module is imported, and the module does not need to be referenced. Note: this is not encouraged and is bad practice as it makes it unclear which module a function is from and pollutes the namespace.‚óè Aliasing using as. This modifies the name of the module during referencing. It is done when the module‚Äôs name is too long or has already been used in the program.In this lab and all future labs, we will be using OpenCV. Please ensure you have installed the OpenCV library, which was discussed in the previous lab sheet.Import the OpenCV library using import cv2.2. Whole Image OperationsReading and writing images is achieved via the imread and imwrite functions, while imshow displays images in a window. Using the image cameraman.tif from the Moodle page, perform the following:‚óè Read it in using imread.‚óè Display it using imshow (Hint: Remember to use waitKey to keep the window displayed).‚óè Write it to a new file using imwrite.shape can provide basic information about the image.‚óè Use shape on the image and print the results. How many values do you get, and what|if‚Äô University of |W Nottingham UK | CHINA | MALAYSIASchool of Computer ScienceCOMP2032 Laboratory Sheet 2: HistogramsWe will be using the Matplotlib library to create and display the histograms of the images. Matplotlib is a data visualisation and plotting library for Python which contains functions similar to the ones in MATLAB. Install the Matplotlib library and import it using from matplotlib import pyplot as plt as only the pyplot module is needed. This is the official documentation for the pyplot module https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/pyplot_summary.html.1. Creating HistogramsHistograms are often used in image processing to visualise and provide valuable information on the pixel distributions and function as a tool to assist in performing various image processing techniques. Read an RGB image (You may use the Tulip.jpeg image from the Moodle page).‚óè Create and display a histogram for each colour channel in the image using hist (Hint: Use ravel from Matplotlib).‚óè Convert the image to HSV and display the histograms of the hue and saturation channels. What should the number of bins be?‚óè Convert the image to greyscale and view the effects of changing the number of bins in the|trouble searching for a conjunction of colors, as is done in the Histogram Backproduction algorithm. Until now, there has been no work in how color is used for identifica- tion or location in biological systems. This article pro- vides computational models whose presence could be explored in biological systems.AcknowledgmentsLambert Wixson, Chris Brown, Randal Nelson, and the Rochester vision group were a source of influential discussions and ideas, Thanks to Ketan Mulmuley for help with the theorem in Appendix B. Ray Rimey and the reviewers made careful comments on the manuscript. This work was supported by NSF research grant DCR- 8602958 and ONR research grant NO0014-91-J-1185.Color Indexing 25Appendix A: Relation to Pattern RecognitionEach of the different bins of the histogram can be considered a different feature, as is done in pattern recognition (Young & Fu 1986). This approach to recognition has been studied extensively, and so it is important to discuss Histogram Intersection in relation to the approaches used in this disciplinc.In pattern recognition, the set of features are designated to be axes in a feature space, in which the object is defined to be a point (fi, ...,|if‚Äô University of |W Nottingham UK | CHINA | MALAYSIASchool of Computer ScienceCOMP2032 Laboratory Sheet 1A: Image Processing in PythonOpenCV is an open-source library of functions related to computer vision, image processing and machine learning. Some other notable libraries would be Pillow (PIL) and sci-kit image. In this module, we will be using OpenCV as the main image processing library. You may read the official documentation to better understand the functions available https://docs.opencv.org/4.x/d6/d00/tutorial_py_root.html.1. Using LibrariesTo use the libraries in Python, they must be imported using import. It is encouraged and good practice to import libraries at the beginning of the file. import is used to access the code in a Python module, which is a Python file containing a set of functions and classes (essentially what a library is). We can also create our own modules to organise code by grouping it, improving code readability and reusability.‚óè Using import. The entire module is imported, and the module must be referenced when used.‚óè Using from‚Ä¶ import. The specified functions are imported, and the module does not need to be referenced.‚óè Using from‚Ä¶ import *. The|them perfectly flat or approximate the view in the database. Since this experiment tests the ‚Äò‚Äòwhat‚Äù or identification problem, the panning is done so that the image serves as a fovea, that is, each shirt, when centered, occupies the major- ity of the image. Nevertheless, the shirts are close enough that there is often another shirt in the background when a match is being done. The shirt oc- cupying the major portion of the image is invariably the top notch.As discussed at the beginning of this section, it is expected that a color-constancy algorithm be used before histogramming. Nonetheless, we tested Histo- gram Intersection in the presence of changing light in- tensity without color constancy. One aim is to see how necessary a color-constancy algorithm is. As we ex- pected, changes in lighting conditions affect the match value considerably. More importantly, this experiment can be also used to test how well a color-constancy algorithm must work. Changing light intensity was simulated by multiplying the image pixel values by a constant factor ranging from 0.4 to 1.6. The resulting pixel values were constrained to be no greater than 255, as would occur in a camera. The

input: Where can I find the datasets for the coursework?
actual_output: Based on the retrieved context from the course materials, the datasets for your coursework appear to be located in a specific directory structure on your local machine or the system you are using for the module. According to the provided code snippet from `DataLoader.py` (likely from Laboratory Sheet 9 - CNN), the dataset for the MNIST example is expected to be found at: - `"./MNIST/mnist_train/"` for the training partition - `"./MNIST/mnist_test/"` for the test partition This suggests that you should have a folder named `MNIST` in your current working directory, containing the `mnist_train` and `mnist_test` subfolders. **If you cannot locate these datasets:** 1. They may have been provided to you via the module's Moodle page or another university system. 2. You might need to download them from an official source as instructed in your coursework brief. For specific guidance on where to find or download the exact datasets required for your assignment, I recommend: - Checking the Moodle page for the "Introduction to Image Processing" module - Reviewing your coursework specification document - Contacting the teaching assistant, Mr. Irfan Yaqub (Email: hcxiy1@nottingham.edu.my), for direct assistance with dataset access The module convenor, Dr. Tissa Chandesa (Tissa.Chandesa@nottingham.edu.my), could also provide clarification if needed. *Since I don't have specific information about dataset locations, I recommend contacting Dr. Chandesa directly:* Email Dr. Chandesa
expected_output: You can download the datasets from Moodle‚Äôs coursework page.
